docs.lead_paragraph: With the recent passage of two state ballot measures banning same-sex marriage, opinion polls and advocates on both sides of the debate say similar initiatives are likely to be approved in as many as 10 other states in November, leading advocates of such marriages to pour money and manpower into a last stand in Oregon. ''Everything seems to point to a tougher battle in Oregon than it has been elsewhere,'' said Gary Bauer, chairman of the Campaign for Working Families, a political action committee supporting constitutional amendments that would only legally recognize marriage as between a man and a woman. ''But I still think my side's got a good chance there.''

headline.main: Voters in 10 of 11 States Are Seen as Likely to Pass Bans of Same-Sex Marriages

docs.abstract: Opinion polls and advocates on both sides of debate expect a many as 10 states to pass ballot measures banning same-sex marriage; voters in Missouri and Louisiana approved constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage last month; proposed bans appear on ballot in 11 states; several, but not all, are solid supporters of Pres Bush; photos; map (M)
docs.snippet: Advocates of same-sex marriages are pouring money and manpower into a last stand in Oregon.

byline.original: By SARAH KERSHAW and JAMES DAO

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of teachers and school workers marched to state lawmakers' homes and to the Capitol to protest Gov. Ernie Fletcher's proposed increases in health insurance costs. The Kentucky Education Association promised a strike on Oct. 27 if costs were not brought in line with those of nearby states. Albert Salvato (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Teachers Protest Insurance Costs

docs.abstract: Thousands of teachers and school workers in Kentucky march to state lawmakers' homes and Capitol to protest proposed increases in health insurance costs; Kentucky Education Assn threatens to strike on Oct 27 over issue (S)
docs.snippet: Thousands of teachers and school workers marched to state lawmakers' homes and to the Capitol to protest Gov. Ernie Fletcher's proposed increases in health insurance costs. The Kentucky Education Association promised a strike on Oct. 27 if costs were...

docs.lead_paragraph: The annual conference of the Labor Party of Prime Minister Tony Blair opened here on Monday under the pall of the war in Iraq as the fate of a British hostage, Ken Bigley, remained uncertain, and family members and British Muslims made new appeals for his release. Mr. Blair had hoped to use the Labor gathering at this seaside resort on Britain's south coast as the platform from which to lead the party into a record-setting third term when elections are called as early as next May. He had hoped to shift the national debate away from the war and onto domestic goals for education, national health care and jobs.

headline.main: Iraq's Gloom Overshadows Yearly Meeting Of Blair's Party

docs.abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair's Labor Party holds annual conference under pall of war in Iraq; fate of British hostage Ken Bigley remains uncertain and family members and British Muslims make new appeals for his release; 11 days of hostage coverage--now centered on Bigley after his two American colleagues were beheaded--has proved politically corrosive for Blair and his party; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The annual conference of the Labor Party opened under the pall of the war in Iraq as the fate of a British hostage remained uncertain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Alfred Szymanski could not seem to get his blood pressure under control. He ran 10 miles a week, stuck to a healthy diet and was on a hypertension medication, all to no avail. His doctor suggested switching medications, but Mr. Szymanski, wary of side effects, decided to try something he had always wondered about: acupuncture. After three 20-minute sessions, each covered by his medical plan, his blood pressure plunged 20 points.
docs.abstract: Acupuncture, which has been shunned by mainstream medical community, is gaining legitimate ground with several new studies showing acupuncture's benefits; Kaiser Family Foundation and Health Research and Educational Trust survey finds that nearly 50 percent of workers have acupuncture included in health benefits, which is up from only 30 percent two years ago; acupuncture is only alternative therapy to have extensive government-financed testing from as early as 1970's; animals are now being given acupuncture to relieve pain; Chicago veterinarian Barbara Royal holds her business administering acupuncture to animals is non-stop; common uses for acupuncture described; proposed industry regulations discussed; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Acupuncture, long shunned by mainstream medicine, is slowly gaining ground in doctors' offices around the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators said Monday that the Bush administration had improperly allowed some private health plans to limit Medicare patients' choice of health care providers, including doctors, nursing homes and home care agencies. The investigators, from the Government Accountability Office, also said that the private plans had increased out-of-pocket costs for the elderly and had not saved money for the government, contrary to predictions by Medicare officials.

headline.main: Inquiry on Medicare Finds Improper Limits on Choices

docs.abstract: General Accountability Office investigators say Bush administration has improperly allowed some private health plans to limit Medicare patients' choice of health care providers, including doctors, nursing homes and home care agencies; say private plans have increased out-of-pocket costs for elderly and have not saved money for government, contrary to predictions by Medicare officials; study is most comprehensive assessment of demonstration project that administration has described as best hope for Medicare's future (M)
docs.snippet: Federal investigators said that the Bush administration had improperly allowed some health plans to limit Medicare patients' choice of health care providers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Trying out themes for their debate on Thursday, the presidential candidates swung at each other over Iraq on Monday, with President Bush mocking Senator John Kerry as indecisive under pressure and Mr. Kerry accusing him of ''refusing to come clean with the American people.'' ''It's been a little tough to prepare for the debates, because he keeps changing his positions, especially on the war,'' Mr. Bush said at a rally here that the Secret Service said was his biggest of the year, with 41,000 people passing through metal detectors to enter Voice of America park. ''I think he could spend 90 minutes debating himself.''

headline.main: Trading Charges Over Iraq While Preparing for Debate

docs.abstract: Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry trade charges over Iraq in various campaign stops, trying out themes for their debate; campaigns also run advertisements on Iraq that underline each candidate's main lines of attack; photo (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush mocked Senator John Kerry as indecisive under pressure and Mr. Kerry accused him of "refusing to come clean with the American people."

byline.original: By JODI WILGOREN and ROBIN TONER; Jodi Wilgoren reported from West Chester for this article, and Robin Toner reported from Spring Green, Wis

docs.lead_paragraph: State law enforcement officers rallied in Trenton on Monday for a new contract that would include 12 percent annual pay raises and continued out-of-network medical benefits. As part of the protest, more than 1,000 corrections officers called in sick to attend the rally, according to state and labor officials. The 6,811-member union that represents New Jersey's corrections and parole officers and park rangers has been without a contract since July 2003. The union is seeking a wage increase of 12 percent a year for the four years of the contract, and continued health care from providers of their own choosing included in the wage package. The Associated Press estimated that 3,000 people took part in the two-hour rally, which was held in front of the State House.

headline.main: Corrections Officers Stage RallyFor 12% Annual Pay Raises

docs.abstract: New Jersey corrections and parole officers stage rally in Trenton for new contract that would include 12 percent annual pay raises and continuated out-of-network health benefits; union has been without contract since July 2003; photo (M)
docs.snippet: State law enforcement officers rallied in Trenton for a new contract that would include 12 percent annual pay raises.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nassau County government, whose wayward finances flirted with insolvency even during the booming 1990's, has regained its A-range rating from all three major credit rating agencies for the first time in a dozen years. Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service raised Nassau's credit rating for general obligation bonds from the B range on Monday, joining an earlier upgrade by the other agency, Fitch Ratings. S&P assigned the county an A-minus rating; Moody's, an A3, with the ''3'' also indicating a low rating within the A range. Fitch raised its rating to A-minus earlier this year.

headline.main: Nassau County's Credit Ratings Back in 'A' Range

docs.abstract: Nassau County, NY, whose finances flirted with insolvency during last decade, regains its A-range rating from all three major credit agencies for first time in 12 years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae Agrees To Make Major Changes Fannie Mae, the nation's largest mortgage buyer and a financial juggernaut that affects the lives of tens of millions of home buyers, agreed to sweeping changes in an unusual agreement reached after a week of negotiations with the company's federal regulator.

docs.lead_paragraph: For Vice President Dick Cheney's weeklong campaign swing, little was left to chance. Or so it seemed. Campaign advance workers for each of the rallies and town hall or round-table discussions chose every participant, combing lists of Republican activists and donors.

headline.main: Cheney Crowds Would Like More on Kitchen-Table Issues

docs.abstract: Republican activists and donors attending events during Vice Pres Dick Cheney's weeklong campaign swing are surprised to hear his dark message about world events, which is out of sync with what many in ardently supportive audience want to hear; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Vice President Dick Cheney's message on terrorism has been out of sync with what many of his supporters want to hear: his stand on domestic social issues.
